an4.40:4.1: Then Udāyī the brahmin went up to the Buddha,
an4.40:4.5: Nor do I criticize all sacrifices. …
an4.40:4.6: Take the kind of sacrifice where cattle, goats and sheep, chickens and pigs and various kinds of animals are slaughtered.
an4.40:4.7: I don’t praise that kind of violent sacrifice.
an4.40:5.1: But take the kind of sacrifice where cattle, goats and sheep, chickens and pigs and various kinds of animals are not slaughtered.
an4.40:5.2: I do praise that kind of non-violent sacrifice; for example, a regular giving or a traditional family sacrifice. …”
an4.40:6.1: A sacrifice at the right time,
an4.40:6.2: which is allowable and deliberately non-violent,
an4.40:7.1: The Buddhas—who have drawn back the veil from the world,
an4.40:7.4: as they are expert in sacrifice.
an4.40:8.1: When you’ve prepared a suitable offering,
an4.40:8.2: whether as sacrifice or for ancestors,
an4.40:8.4: in the fertile field of spiritual practitioners.
an4.40:9.1: When it’s well-gotten, well-offered and well-sacrificed,
an4.40:9.2: to those worthy of a teacher’s offering,
an4.40:9.4: and even the gods are pleased.
an4.40:10.2: sacrifices like this, with a mind of letting go,
